org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver

Interface TemplateLoadingSource

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    URLTemplateLoadingSource

    public interface TemplateLoadingSource
extends Serializable
    The point of TemplateLoadingSource is that with their Object.equals(Object) method we can tell if two cache entries were generated from the same physical resource or not. Comparing the template names isn't enough, because a TemplateLoader may uses some kind of fallback mechanism, such as delegating to other TemplateLoader-s until the template is found. Like if we have two FileTemplateLoader-s with different physical root directories, both can contain "foo/bar.ftl", but obviously the two files aren't the same.

    When implementing this interface, check these:

    • Object.equals(Object) must not be based on object identity, because two instances of TemplateLoadingSource that describe the same resource must be equivalent.
    • Each TemplateLoader implementation should have its own TemplateLoadingSource implementation, so that TemplateLoadingSource-s coming from different TemplateLoader implementations can't be accidentally equal (according to Object.equals(Object)).
    • Object.equals(Object) must still work properly if there are multiple instances of the same TemplateLoader implementation. Like if you have an implementation that loads from a database table, the TemplateLoadingSource should certain contain the JDBC connection string, the table name and the row ID, not just the row ID.
    • Together with Object.equals(Object), Object.hashCode() must be also overridden. The template source may be used as a HashMap key.
    • Because TemplateLoadingSource-s are Serializable, they can't contain non-Serializable fields. Most notably, a reference to the creator TemplateLoader, so if it's an inner class of the TemplateLoader, it should be static.
    • Consider that cache entries, in which the source is stored, may move between JVM-s (because of clustering with a distributed cache). Thus they should remain meaningful for the purpose of Object.equals(Object) even in another JVM.
    • A TemplateLoader may chose not to support distributed caches, like ByteArrayTemplateLoader doesn't support that for example. In that case the serialization related points above can be ignored, but the TemplateLoadingSource implementation should define the writeObject method (a Java serialization feature) and throw an exception there to block serialization attempts.
